content: The characteristic strength of concrete mass is that value of strength below which not more than “X” percent of test result are expected to fall. What is the value of “X”?
The 28 days characteristic cylindrical compressive strength of concrete of class C20/25 is:
Among the following which can be considered as possible stress-strain curve for concrete as per ES EN 2015:

options.label: A
options.content: A perfect straight line up to failure

options.label: B
options.content: Straight line up to 0.002 strain value and then parabolic up to failure

options.label: C
options.content: Parabolic up to 0.002 strain value and then straight line up to failure

options.label: D
options.content: Hyperbolic up to 0.002 strain value and then straight line up to failure

content: Why is it important to limit the depth of neutral axis in reinforced concrete beams?

options.label: A
options.content: To ensure that the beam has sufficient shear capacity

options.label: B
options.content: To ensure that the beam has sufficient flexural stiffness

options.label: C
options.content: To ensure that the beam has sufficient ductility and avoids brittle failure

options.label: D
options.content: To ensure that the beam has sufficient bond strength between concrete and steel

content: A simply supported beam is required to carry a permanent load of 21kN/m including self-weight over an effective span of 6.0m. this beam shall be designed for a factored bending moment in limit state method of:
In a RCC beam the shear force is carried by:
What is the range of variable inclination of concrete struts in the variable strut inclination method for shear design according to Eurocode 1992?
In the case of two way slab, the deflection of the slab is:

options.label: A
options.content: Primarily a function of long span

options.label: B
options.content: Primarily a function of short span

content: Understanding the development of plastic hinges requires knowledge of:

options.label: C
options.content: The curvature of the member at specific points

content: Studying the curvature of members is important for:

options.label: B
options.content: Evaluating their ability to deform without breaking (ductility)

content: Which of the following is false when a designer uses a larger strut inclination angle while designing RC beams for torsion:

options.label: A
options.content: The spacing of link bars increase

options.label: B
options.content: The longitudinal reinforcement required will increase

options.label: C
options.content: The notional concrete strut compression capacity will decrease

content: The torsional longitudinal reinforcement in reinforced concrete beams should be placed at:

options.label: A
options.content: Tension zone of the beam cross-section

options.label: B
options.content: Compression zone of the beam cross-section

options.label: C
options.content: At least one bar at each corner, the others being distributed uniformly around the inner periphery of the links

content: According to the Eurocode standards (ES EN 1992-1-1), what are the limitations on negative moment redistribution based on reinforcement class?

options.label: A
options.content: Class A: 10%, Class B: 15%, Class C: 20%

options.label: B
options.content: Class A: 20%, Class B: 30%, Class C: 30%

options.label: C
options.content: Class A: 80%, Class B: 70%, Class C: 70%

options.label: D
options.content: Class A: Not allowed, Class B: 20%, Class C: 30%

content: Torsion resisting capacity of a given RC section:

options.label: A
options.content: Decrease with decrease in stirrup spacing

options.label: B
options.content: Decrease with increase in longitudinal bars

options.label: C
options.content: Increase with the increase in stirrup and longitudinal steel

options.label: D
options.content: Does not depend upon stirrup and longitudinal steels

content: In the design of a steel tension member, failure can occur due to various mechanisms. Which of the following failure modes is the most critical and leads to sudden failure of the member?
Which of the following is the property of high carbon steel?
What factor primarily influences the effective length of a steel column?

options.label: A
options.content: The self-weight of the column and its material properties.

options.label: B
options.content: The applied axial load and its distribution along the column length.

options.label: C
options.content: The number of bolts or welds used in its connections.

options.label: D
options.content: The support conditions at the ends.

content: Flexural buckling in a steel column occurs when:

options.label: A
options.content: The axial load exceeds the plastic limit of steel.

options.label: B
options.content: The column undergoes local yielding before buckling.

options.label: C
options.content: The column buckles about its weaker principal axis.

options.label: D
options.content: The column bends due to an eccentric axial load

content: Which of the following is true about torsional buckling?

options.label: A
options.content: Failure occurs by bending about shear center in longitudinal axis

options.label: B
options.content: Standard hot rolled shapes are not susceptible to torsional buckling

options.label: C
options.content: It cannot occur with doubly symmetric cross section

options.label: D
options.content: Failure occurs when torsional rigidity of member is greater than bending rigidity

content: A plate girder is designed for long spans where rolled sections are inadequate. Which failure mode is most critical for deep plate girders?

options.label: D
options.content: Torsional failure of the entire girder

content: Which type of bridge is suitable when high clearance is required for ship traffic below?
Which type of bridge is generally more cost-effective for short to medium spans?
What is a benefit of LRFD's flexibility in design?

options.label: A
options.content: It applies a rigid set of rules without exceptions.

options.label: B
options.content: It allows designers to account for specific conditions and uncertainties in their calculations.

options.label: C
options.content: It requires the use of identical load factors for all materials.

options.label: D
options.content: It avoids considering site-specific load conditions.

content: What is the purpose of including a dynamic load allowance (impact factor) in bridge design?

options.label: A
options.content: To account for static vehicular loads

options.label: B
options.content: To consider additional forces due to vehicle acceleration, deceleration, and impact

options.label: C
options.content: To increase the dead load of the bridge

options.label: D
options.content: To reduce the live load effect on the bridge

content: How should bridge design account for the possibility of overloaded vehicles?

options.label: A
options.content: By using standard load models only

options.label: B
options.content: By ignoring the possibility of overloaded vehicles

options.label: C
options.content: By including a factor of safety to account for potential overloading

options.label: D
options.content: By designing the bridge for the maximum legal load only

content: What is the use of influence lines in the context of vehicular loads on bridges?

options.label: A
options.content: To determine the maximum moment and shear due to moving loads

options.label: B
options.content: To calculate the dead load of the bridge

options.label: C
options.content: To design the foundation of the bridge

options.label: D
options.content: To assess the impact of wind loads on the bridge

content: What is the role of multiple presence factors in bridge design?

options.label: A
options.content: To account for the simultaneous presence of multiple vehicles on the bridge

options.label: B
options.content: To consider the effect of a single vehicle on the bridge

options.label: C
options.content: To reduce the overall load on the bridge

options.label: D
options.content: To calculate the dead load of the bridge

content: Which load combination is typically used for checking the ultimate limit state in bridge design?

options.label: C
options.content: Dead load + live load + impact factor + other relevant loads

content: What does the girder distribution factor represent in bridge design?

options.label: A
options.content: The distribution of dead loads among girders

options.label: B
options.content: The distribution of live loads among girders

options.label: C
options.content: The ratio of girder weight to total bridge weight

options.label: D
options.content: The distribution of wind loads among girders

content: When calculating girder distribution factor, how is load sharing between girders typically accounted for?

options.label: C
options.content: By assuming equal load distribution among all girders

content: What is one advantage of using simplified methods (e.g., AASHTO LRFD empirical formulas) for calculating girder distribution factor?

options.label: A
options.content: They provide the most accurate results

options.label: B
options.content: They are quick and easy to apply in preliminary design

options.label: C
options.content: They do not require consideration of load types

options.label: D
options.content: They ignore the effects of girder spacing

content: How does the spacing between girders influence the girder distribution factor?

options.label: A
options.content: Larger spacing decreases the distribution factor

options.label: B
options.content: Smaller spacing increases the distribution factor

options.label: C
options.content: Smaller spacing decreases the distribution factor

options.label: D
options.content: Girder spacing does not affect the distribution factor

content: How does the load distribution typically differ between interior and exterior girders?

options.label: A
options.content: Exterior girders carry more load than interior girders

options.label: B
options.content: Interior girders carry more load than exterior girders

options.label: C
options.content: Load is equally distributed between interior and exterior girders

options.label: D
options.content: Load distribution is not considered for exterior girders

content: Why is the Fatigue Limit State (FLS) important in bridge design?

options.label: A
options.content: To prevent excessive deflections under normal traffic conditions

options.label: B
options.content: To ensure that the bridge can withstand repeated loading cycles without failure

options.label: C
options.content: To account for temperature variations affecting the bridge

options.label: D
options.content: To ensure aesthetic standards are maintained over time

content: How are multiple presence factors used in estimating live loads on bridges?

options.label: A
options.content: By reducing the live load effect based on the number of lanes loaded

options.label: B
options.content: By increasing the live load effect based on the number of lanes loaded

options.label: C
options.content: By applying the same live load to all lanes regardless of vehicle presence

options.label: D
options.content: By ignoring the number of lanes loaded

content: What are live loads in the context of bridge design?

options.label: A
options.content: Permanent loads that do not change over time

options.label: B
options.content: Loads due to vehicles, pedestrians, and other moving objects

options.label: C
options.content: Loads caused by the weight of the bridge structure itself

options.label: D
options.content: Loads due to environmental factors such as wind and temperature

content: How is shear force typically resisted in slab bridges?

options.label: A
options.content: By the vertical stirrups in the slab

options.label: B
options.content: By the horizontal reinforcement in the slab

options.label: C
options.content: By the thickness of the slab and the reinforcement within it

options.label: D
options.content: By the external cables used for prestressing

content: In the analysis of girder bridges, why is both longitudinal and transverse analysis important?

options.label: A
options.content: To account for the effects of wind and earthquakes

options.label: B
options.content: To ensure the bridge can handle traffic in both directions

options.label: C
options.content: To capture the behavior of girders and deck separately, ensuring accurate load distribution and stress calculation

options.label: D
options.content: To reduce the overall cost of the bridge construction distribution and stress calculation

content: Which design philosophy is adopted by AASHTO for bridge design?
How are limit states addressed in AASHTO LRFD?

options.label: B
options.content: By considering only one limit state

options.label: C
options.content: By considering multiple limit states such as strength, serviceability, and fatigue

options.label: D
options.content: By considering only strength limit states

content: In what situations might the multiple presence factor be used for a single-lane bridge?

options.label: A
options.content: During the design of a pedestrian bridge

options.label: B
options.content: During the design of a bridge with low traffic volume

options.label: C
options.content: During the design of a bridge with high traffic volume

options.label: D
options.content: During the design of a bridge with a single lane

content: How do properly designed distribution bars contribute to the longevity of bridge decks?

options.label: A
options.content: By increasing the rate of corrosion

options.label: B
options.content: By reducing the load-carrying capacity of the bridge deck

options.label: C
options.content: By minimizing the development of cracks and deterioration

options.label: D
options.content: By increasing the weight of the bridge

content: What does the hydrological assessment of a bridge site involve?

options.label: A
options.content: Evaluating the water quality of nearby rivers

options.label: B
options.content: Measuring the air humidity of the site

options.label: C
options.content: Assessing the water flow, depth, and velocity of nearby water bodies

options.label: D
options.content: Studying the aquatic life in the vicinity

content: In the context of bridge design, what is a "live load surcharge"?

options.label: A
options.content: An additional static load applied to the bridge

options.label: B
options.content: A reduced load to account for future weight increases

options.label: C
options.content: An extra load added to account for unexpected live load increases

options.label: D
options.content: A load factor applied during wind loading analysis

content: In the context of low-level water crossings, what does the term "overtopping" refer to?

options.label: A
options.content: The maximum allowable height of the crossing

options.label: B
options.content: The water flow exceeding the capacity of the structure

options.label: C
options.content: The process of placing the final layer of pavement

options.label: D
options.content: The design of the handrails for pedestrian safety

content: What is the primary risk associated with low-level water crossings during flood events?

options.label: A
options.content: Structural failure due to high wind speeds

content: Which design feature helps prevent erosion at the entry and exit points of a low-level water crossing?
What type of movement is a reinforced elastomeric bearing designed to accommodate?
What is a low-level water crossing primarily designed to accommodate?
How is the suitability of a bridge site assessed?

options.label: A
options.content: By selecting the most challenging terrain

options.label: B
options.content: By evaluating geological, hydrological, and environmental factors

options.label: C
options.content: By prioritizing aesthetic appeal over functionality

content: In seismic area, which one of the following has most negative effect on the dam stability?

options.label: A
options.content: If the horizontal acceleration due to earthquake is acting to u/s towards empty reservoir.

options.label: B
options.content: If the horizontal acceleration due to earthquake is acting to u/s towards full reservoir.

options.label: C
options.content: If the vertical acceleration due to earthquake is acting upward to the dam body.

content: Which one of the following is incorrect about the uplift pressure under a gravity dam?

options.label: A
options.content: If there is a gallery, uplift pressure distribution will be decreased.

options.label: B
options.content: If there is no tail water, the uplift pressure distribution will be increased.

options.label: C
options.content: Uplift pressure is always having zero distribution if there is tension crack under the dam.

content: Which of the following is incorrect about the hydraulic structures?

options.label: A
options.content: Straight gravity dams resist some external forces by arch action.

options.label: B
options.content: All Arch dams resist all forces including it weight by arch action transferring to the abutments.

options.label: C
options.content: Embankment dams will fail by overturning.

content: Which one is incorrect about foundation of dams?

options.label: A
options.content: We can construction high gravity dams on fine grain material foundations.

options.label: B
options.content: Embankment dams are not suitable to construct on rock foundation as gravity dam cannot be constructed on coarse grained materials.

options.label: C
options.content: Curtain grouting is used to strengthen carrying capacity of the foundation

content: Dam storage has different components and out lets. Which of the following is incorrect about these components?

options.label: A
options.content: Dead storage is used to store water for the any further required purpose of the storage.

options.label: B
options.content: Bottom outlet is used to withdraw water for our live storage.

options.label: C
options.content: Live storage is the component which is used to store sediment.

content: Which one is incorrect about the stability of concrete gravity dams?

options.label: A
options.content: For full reservoir if the resultant of all external forces passes outside the middle third, tension will develop at the toe.

options.label: B
options.content: For empty reservoir if the resultant of all external forces passes outside the middle third to the heel direction, tension will develop at the toe.

options.label: C
options.content: If the principal stress is less than the compressive strength of the concrete, the dam will fail due to crushing.

content: Dam spillways can be classified based on their purpose such as main spillway, auxiliary spillway and emergency spillway. An emergency spillway will be functional for emergency cases only. Which one of the following can’t be the possible cases/reasons/ for emergency?

options.label: A
options.content: when the actual flood exceeds the design flood

options.label: B
options.content: when there is malfunctioning of the main dam outlets

options.label: C
options.content: when the gates of spillway are not working

options.label: D
options.content: when the actual flood does not exceed the design flood

content: If low height Arch dam with d/s face of nearly vertical is proposed to be constructed on river X with narrow gorge and steeply rises abutment, which type of spillway will be the most appropriate?
Which one of the following types of spillways is not usually recommended for high dams due to the structure’s instability problem?

Different energy dissipator measures that can be adopted at the toe of the spillway depends upon the relative positions of jump height curve (JHC) and tail water rating curve (TWRC). In the plotting of JHC and TWRC, if the values of tail water depths in the river downstream of a spillway toe are less than the values of the corresponding sequent depths for all discharges, which one of the following is not the possible measure that can be provided at the toe of the spillway for dissipation of excess energy?

options.label: B
options.content: providing secondary dam (weir) d/s of the toe of the spillway

options.label: C
options.content: providing sloping apron above the river bed

options.label: D
options.content: providing sloping apron below the river bed

content: Which one of the following is not correctly matched?

options.label: A
options.content: Canal head regulator- used to separate floor levels of the under sluices and the main weir section

options.label: B
options.content: Divide wall- constructed at the head of a canal taking off

options.label: C
options.content: Fish ladder - constructed on the bed of the river, upstream of the head regulator

content: Which type of spillway is ideally suited for a very high dams in which the energy can’t be dissipated by a hydraulic jump or bucket?
Which type of spillway component is used to dissipate energy at the toe of the spillway?
Which one of the following is not a correct statement?

options.label: A
options.content: If tail water depth is either too small or too large for the formation of perfect hydraulic jump at the toe of the spillway, bucket type energy dissipator is not the only option that should be provided for the dissipation of high energy.

options.label: B
options.content: The most effective energy dissipation in overflow spillway design is when the tail water rating curve (TWRC) overlaps with the jump height curve (JHC) for all discharge rates.

options.label: C
options.content: The amount of energy dissipation in a hydraulic jump increases as the Froude number increases.

options.label: D
options.content: The amount of energy dissipation in a hydraulic jump decreases as the Froude number increases.

content: What will be the possible measures that should be adopted at the toe of an overflow spillway for the dissipation of energy for the case when the jump height curve is lying below the tail water rating curve for all discharges?

options.label: A
options.content: Providing secondary dam/weir/ d/s of the toe of the spillway

options.label: B
options.content: By providing a sloping apron above the river bed

options.label: C
options.content: By providing a sloping apron below the river bed

Strength of concrete with passage of time

content: Portland pozzolana cement possesses
The Vicat Apparatus is used to check

content: Which one of the following is not the components of a site plan?

options.label: B
options.content: Columns are a vertical load bearing members of the structural frame which transmits the beam loads down to the foundations.

content: Pick up the incorrect statement about steel from the following

options.label: A

content: Pick up the incorrect statement about the Requirements of a Foundation

options.label: A
options.content: The foundations shall be constructed to sustain all loads and transmit them to the sub soil without causing settlement which would impair the stability of the building or adjoining structure.

options.label: B
options.content: Foundation base should be rigid so that differential settlements are minimised, specially for the case when super-imposed loads are not evenly distributed.

options.label: C
options.content: Foundation should be taken sufficiently deep to guard the building against damage or distress caused by swelling or shrinkage of sub-soil.

options.label: D
options.content: Foundations should be ideally located so that its performance may be affected due to any unexpected future influence

content: Which of the following is the correct statement about raft foundation?

options.label: D
options.content: It is not used where the allowable soil pressure is low

content: Pick up the incorrect statement from the following about Building construction drawings

options.label: A
options.content: The floor plan is a drawing of the outline and partitions of a building that would be seen when the building was cut horizontally about 1.2m above the floor level.

options.label: B
options.content: Elevation drawings are orthographic drawings of the interior of a building.

options.label: C
options.content: Sectional drawings reveal the internal construction of an object.

content: Which of the following is not true about flooring systems in the building?

options.label: A
options.content: They prevent dampness inside the building by providing a damp proof membrane in or below the floor.

options.label: B
options.content: Suspended ground floor is needed where soils containing aggressive chemicals, and/or sites with high water levels.

options.label: C
options.content: Waffle slab flooring is a floor system consisting of closely spaced secondary beams (ribs) which transfer load to the main beam/girder that will in turn transfer the load to columns or walls.

options.label: D
options.content: The choice of floor finishes depends on the initial cost, appearance, durability, damp resistance, smoothness and maintenance.

content: Which of the following is the correct production process of brick production?

options.label: A
options.content: If there are two doors in a room, the doors should preferably be located in opposite walls facing each other

options.label: B
options.content: A dormer window is a vertical window provided in the gable end of a pitched roof.

options.content: A door should preferably be located near the corner of a room –nearly 20cm away from the corner.

options.label: D
options.content: Louvered doors permit free ventilation through them, and at the same time maintain the privacy of the room.

content: Which one of the following is not a damp prevention mechanism?

options.content: Adding an impervious layer of rich cement mortar over the exposed surfaces for resisting water pressure as a process of pressure grouting.

options.label: B
options.content: Surface treatment, Pressure grouting& Cavity wall construction

content: Pick the incorrect statement from the following about Building finishes.

content: Which one of the following is true about Formwork in building construction?

options.label: B

content: To prevent failure of formwork the following precautions should be taken,

content: All are the requirements of a good roof, except

options.label: A

content: The term used to describe the ratio between the volume of water contained within a specific soil mass and the total volume of its voids is known as
Select the statement from the following options that is not correct:

options.label: A
options.content: A maximum value of dry density is obtained at optimum water content

options.label: B
options.content: At low value of water content most soils tend to be soft.

options.label: C
options.content: At high water content, the dry density decreases with an increase of water content.

options.label: D

options.label: C

content: Select the incorrect statement from the following:

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.content: The percent settlement at any time is called degree of consolidation

options.label: C

content: For general engineering purposes, soils are classified by

options.label: C

Which one of the following is not Tergazhi's theory of one dimensional consolidation assumptions?

options.label: A
options.content: load is applied in one direction

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.content: Both pipes will experience the same stress increase.

options.label: D
options.content: Stress increment depends only on the pipe material and not on depth.

options.label: B

content: A sample of soil is classified as A-7(20) under the AASHTO classification system. What does the group index (20) indicate?

options.label: A
options.content: The soil is a good subgrade material

options.label: C
options.content: The soil has very poor subgrade properties

content: Which one of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.content: Void ratio and porosity can be possibly larger than 1.0

options.label: B
options.content: Dry density of the soil is the mass of solids to volume of solids

options.label: C
options.content: Liquid limit is the minimum water content at which the soil will flow under its own weight.

options.label: D
options.content: A well graded soil will have a uniformity coefficient greater than about 6 for gravels and 4 for sands, and a coefficient of gradation between 1 and 3

content: Triaxial tests are commonly used in geotechnical engineering to measure the shear strength parameters of soils. Which of the following statements about triaxial tests is correct?

options.label: A
options.content: The UU test is used to evaluate the long-term stability of slopes in cohesive soils.

options.label: B
options.content: The CD test measures both total and effective shear strength parameters in a single test.

options.label: C
options.content: The CU test is effective for determining both total and effective shear strength parameters in fine-grained soils.

options.label: D
options.content: All triaxial tests are equally suitable to determine the shear strength of any types of soil.

content: Which one of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.content: For soil that compresses or contracts during drained loading, excess pore water pressure under undrained condition is positive.

options.label: B
options.content: During undrained loading, the soil volume remains constant.

options.label: C
options.content: If the soil is compressed under a certain pressure and then expands under a lower pressure, it will be normally consolidated

The active earth pressure exerted by a cohesionless backfill on a smooth vertical wall can be reduced by:

options.label: D

content: A soil sample from a construction site is subjected to an Unconsolidated Undrained triaxial test. The results show that the deviator stress at failure remains constant regardless of the cell pressure. What does this indicate about the soil?

options.label: A
options.content: The soil is cohesive and fully saturated

options.label: B
options.content: The soil is granular and well-compacted

options.label: C
options.content: The soil is partially saturated with a high permeability

options.label: D
options.content: The soil has a high friction angle

content: The reduction in bearing capacity due to a rising water table is primarily caused by
What is the primary characteristic of undisturbed soil?

options.label: A
options.content: Soil structure is altered during sampling

options.label: B
options.content: Soil structure remains intact and natural

options.label: C
options.content: Soil is mixed with foreign materials

content: During foundation design, if the ultimate bearing capacity of a soil is 600 kPa, and the bearing capacity due to the settlement criteria is 150 kPa, with a factor of safety of 3 for the foundation soil, which one of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.content: The allowable bearing capacity is 150 kPa

options.label: B
options.content: The allowable bearing capacity is 200 kPa

options.label: C
options.content: The allowable bearing capacity is 600 kPa

options.label: D
options.content: The allowable bearing capacity is 300 kPa

content: In the structural design of a footing, what is the primary goal of proportioning?

options.label: A
options.content: To minimize the cost of construction materials

options.label: B
options.content: To ensure the footing dimensions are aesthetically pleasing

options.label: C
options.content: To distribute the load evenly and prevent excessive settlement or failure

options.label: D
options.content: To reduce the thickness of the footing as much as possible

content: What is the basic principle of proportioning a combined rectangular footing?

options.label: A
options.content: The footing dimensions should be equal to the sum of the individual column loads.

options.label: B
options.content: The centroid of the footing should coincide with the resultant of the column loads.

options.label: C
options.content: The footing should be designed to minimize the use of concrete.

options.label: D
options.content: The footing should have a width equal to the largest column dimension.

content: When selecting between spread footings and mat foundations, under what conditions is it NOT advisable to use a mat foundation?

options.label: A
options.content: When the soil has good bearing capacity to support the building loads.

options.label: B
options.content: When the total area of spread footings is greater than 50% of the building plinth area.

options.label: C
options.content: When the soil bearing capacity is exceptionally low for spread footings.

options.label: D
options.content: When differential settlement occurs between spread footings.

content: Which of the following factors is NOT typically considered in the analysis and design of retaining structures?

options.label: A
options.content: Soil properties and lateral earth pressures.

options.label: C
options.content: The aesthetic appearance of the retaining wall.

options.label: D
options.content: Factors of safety against sliding and overturning.
